title: TALK OF THE TOWN: Kate Beckinsale and Jonathan Voluck dress as Audrey Hepburn and Elton John
text:
Never thought I’d see Audrey Hepburn and Elton John perusing the snacks aisle of a corner shop together – it must be nearly Halloween!

On closer inspection that’s Kate Beckinsale celebrating America’s favourite holiday with pal Jonathan Voluck.

They stopped off for a late-night supermarket sweep after a star-studded LA bash on Friday night.

The Underworld actress dressed as Hepburn’s character Holly Golightly from the 1961 film Breakfast At Tiffany’s, while Jonathan – an executive at Paramount Television – dressed up as Elton in his famous LA Dodgers kit.

Kate wears fancy dress all year round and famously never travels without a pantomime horse costume in her luggage, so to her it was just an average night out!

DO AS I SAY 1... Cara’s designs destroy her eco credentials

I thought model Cara Delevingne was the perfect eco-celeb

I thought model Cara Delevingne (right) was the perfect eco-celeb – she’s launched her own green campaign and is an ambassador for a clean seas charity. But that was before I discovered that she has just designed a range of cheap, fast-fashion clothes mostly made out of polyester.

Now she’s in hot water with her uncle George Duffield’s Blue Marine Foundation, for which she is an ambassador, over the range for fast-fashion brand Nasty Gal.

Blue Marine, which campaigns against plastic pollution and over-fishing, described her decision to unveil the collection last week as ‘surprising’ and ‘not in line with the charity’.

The range features various ‘pleather’ items including a £17.50 shirt – despite the fact Cara, 27, knows better than most that fast-fashion contributes to a third of micro plastics found in the ocean.

Her own environmental campaign, My Eco Resolution, founded in January, states on its website: ‘Fashion has a disastrous impact on the planet and it is the second greatest polluter... stop supporting fast fashion, only buy sustainable fashion, avoid micro-plastics in clothing.’ Unless you’re buying from Cara, I guess...

DO AS I SAY 2

I don’t think designer Melissa Odabash has got to grips with going green.

‘I haven’t driven in months, I walk, jog or cycle everywhere and I am designing swimwear made out of recycled plastic,’ she explained to me last week.

‘But I do still fly a lot, sometimes by private jet.’

Oh dear...
